title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article focuses on the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, emphasizing their frequency and impact. It highlights the challenges posed by weather conditions in the region and mentions relevant news concerning Pinal County. Overall, it underscores the persistent nature of wildfires in Arizona.

title: Brush fire in Tempe being investigated as arson
summary: A brush fire that erupted in Tempe, Arizona, near the Salt River is being investigated as arson. The fire started on the north side of Tempe Town Lake, but fire crews were able to contain it quickly, preventing it from spreading further. Although no injuries were reported, some palm trees and wildlife were damaged. Authorities are looking for a shirtless man seen fleeing the scene, and anyone with information is urged to contact the Tempe Police Department.

title: 2 dead, multiple injured after double mobile home fire in Phoenix
summary: A double mobile home fire in Phoenix on Sunday morning resulted in two fatalities and multiple injuries. Fire crews responded to the scene near 24th Street and Union Hills Drive, where two men in their 30s died after becoming trapped in a room without windows. Three others were hospitalized in stable condition with burn injuries. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, and the mobile home owner, who was renting to one of the victims, lacks insurance and is seeking community support for aid.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting the severity and frequency of the incidents. It emphasizes the impact of weather conditions on the wildfires and mentions updates related to Pinal County. Overall, it underscores the widespread nature of the wildfire situation in the region.

title: Brush fire in Tempe being investigated as arson
summary: A brush fire that erupted Sunday afternoon near the Salt River in Tempe, Arizona, is being investigated as arson. The fire, which damaged palm trees and wildlife but caused no injuries, was quickly contained by the Tempe Fire Department. Authorities reported seeing a shirtless man fleeing the scene, and the investigation is ongoing. As of Monday morning, the fire was mostly extinguished, although a light haze and smell of smoke may still be noticeable for drivers on Loop 202 near McClintock Road. Anyone with information is urged to contact the Tempe Police Department.

title: 2 dead, multiple injured after double mobile home fire in Phoenix
summary: A double mobile home fire in Phoenix resulted in the deaths of two men in their 30s, while three others were hospitalized with burn injuries. The fire occurred near 24th Street and Union Hills Drive on Sunday morning, and witnesses reported that the victims were trapped in a room without windows. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. The mobile home owner, who was renting to one of the deceased, does not have insurance and is receiving support from friends to raise funds.

The fire, which affected some palm trees and wildlife, was quickly contained by the Tempe Fire Department, with no reported injuries. Authorities are looking for a shirtless man seen fleeing the scene, and the investigation continues. Commuters on Loop 202 may notice lingering smoke. Anyone with information is urged to contact the Tempe Police Department.

title: 2 dead, multiple injured after double mobile home fire in Phoenix
summary: A double mobile home fire in Phoenix resulted in the deaths of two men in their 30s and left several others hospitalized with burn injuries. Firefighters responded to the blaze early Sunday morning, where the victims were found trapped in a room without windows. The cause of the fire is still under investigation. The mobile home owner, who was renting to one of the deceased, lacks insurance, and friends are organizing a fundraiser to assist him. Witnesses recounted the chaos and tragedy as they tried to rescue those inside.

title: Surprise firefighter passes away after cancer battle
summary: The Surprise Fire and Medical Department in Arizona is mourning the loss of paramedic Paul Johnson, who passed away after a battle with cancer. Johnson, remembered for his compassion and dedication, leaves behind a wife and three young children. The department expressed their sorrow and commitment to honoring his memory while offering support for his family's funeral costs through a GoFundMe campaign.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, emphasizing their prevalence and impact on the region. It mentions various locations affected by the fires, particularly in Pinal County, and highlights the broader context of wildfire occurrences in the U.S. and around the world.

title: Fire at Salt River near Loop 202 being investigated as arson
summary: A fire at Salt River near Loop 202 is currently under investigation as a potential case of arson. Authorities are looking into the circumstances surrounding the blaze, which has raised concerns about public safety and environmental impact. Further details on the investigation have yet to be released.

title: Deadly fire rips through mobile homes in Phoenix
summary: A devastating fire broke out in a mobile home community in Phoenix, resulting in multiple fatalities and significant property damage. Emergency responders rushed to the scene to control the blaze, but the rapid spread of the fire complicated rescue efforts. Authorities are investigating the cause of the fire and providing support to those affected.

title: 2 dead, 3 hurt after double mobile home fire in Phoenix
summary: A double mobile home fire in Phoenix resulted in the deaths of two individuals and left three others injured. Emergency responders were dispatched to the scene, where they encountered significant flames. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article focuses on the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting their prevalence and impact in the region. It emphasizes the challenges posed by the weather and the broader implications for both local communities and the environment. The repeated mention of wildfires suggests a significant concern regarding their frequency and severity in Arizona.

title: Power Ranch HOA under fire again, accused of not disclosing lawsuit to new homebuyers
summary: Residents of Power Ranch Community in Gilbert, Arizona, are expressing concerns after new homeowners discovered that the homeowners association (HOA) did not disclose an ongoing lawsuit when they purchased their homes. Shelly Law, a new resident, highlighted the lack of transparency about the lawsuit, which could potentially lead to increased HOA dues or affect property resale values. The lawsuit involves the HOA trying to prevent a developer from renting out condo units, and the management company, Capitol Consultants Management Corporation (CCMC), is being criticized for providing misleading information on disclosure forms, violating state law.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in northern Arizona, emphasizing their prevalence and impact on the region. It highlights the severe weather conditions contributing to these wildfires and makes references to various areas affected, including Pinal County. title: 2 dead, multiple injured after double mobile home fire in Phoenix
summary: A double mobile home fire in Phoenix resulted in the deaths of two men in their 30s and left multiple individuals hospitalized with burn injuries. Firefighters responded to the scene early on Sunday morning, where the victims were found trapped in a room without windows. The cause of the fire is still under investigation, and the mobile home owner, who was renting to one of the deceased, is seeking community support due to a lack of insurance. Witnesses expressed their shock and sorrow over the incident, highlighting the victims as fathers.

title: Person displaced, pet dead after mobile home fire in north Phoenix
summary: A fire in a mobile home in north Phoenix on Sunday morning left one person displaced and resulted in the death of their pet. The Phoenix Fire Department responded quickly to extinguish the flames, reporting no injuries but confirming the home was destroyed and another animal is missing. A Community Assistance Program is assisting the affected individual, while the cause of the fire is currently under investigation.

title: Phoenix-based casual pizza joint Fired Pie files for bankruptcy
summary: Fired Pie, a casual pizza chain based in Phoenix, has filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in an effort to restructure its business. The company, which has been operating since 2013 and currently has 14 locations, reported assets of up to $1 million against liabilities of up to $10 million. Factors contributing to its financial struggles include the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic and increased competition in the pizza market.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting the severity and frequency of these incidents. It emphasizes the impact of weather conditions on the wildfires and mentions the broader context of wildfires affecting the U.S. and the world. Additionally, it references local news related to Pinal County.

title: Brush fire in Tempe being investigated as arson
summary: A brush fire that broke out Sunday afternoon near the Salt River in Tempe, Arizona, is being investigated as arson. The fire, which occurred on the north side of Tempe Town Lake, was quickly contained by crews, preventing further damage. Some palm trees and wildlife were destroyed, but no injuries were reported. Authorities are looking for a shirtless man seen fleeing the scene and are asking anyone with information to contact the Tempe Police Department.

title: Arson suspected after massive fire at Apache Junction housing development
summary: The Apache Junction Police Department is investigating a significant fire at a housing development site as a suspected case of arson. The fire, which occurred late Tuesday night, completely engulfed two new homes under construction near Idaho Road and Tepee Street. Firefighters had to adopt a defensive approach due to the intensity of the flames, but no injuries were reported. Authorities are actively seeking information from the public regarding the incident.

title: Gilbert Fire holds free car seat education class for parents
summary: Gilbert Fire & Rescue in Gilbert, AZ, is offering free car seat education classes to help ensure children's safety in vehicles. Parents can have their car seats checked and learn proper installation techniques from certified technicians. The next class is scheduled for December 14, emphasizing the fire department's commitment to community safety.

title: Crews battle massive fire at new housing development in Apache Junction
summary: Firefighters battled a massive blaze late Tuesday night at a new housing development in Apache Junction, Arizona. The fire, which broke out shortly before 11:30 p.m. near Idaho Road and Tepee Street, engulfed a construction site, prompting crews to take a defensive approach to prevent the flames from spreading to nearby homes. Fortunately, no injuries were reported, and investigators are currently working to determine the cause of the fire.

title: Lanes reopen after semi-truck fire on Loop 101 in Scottsdale
summary: All lanes of Loop 101 in Scottsdale have reopened after a semi-truck fire on Tuesday morning near Hayden Road. Firefighters responded to the scene, where heavy smoke was visible, and the driver escaped without injury. The westbound lanes were closed for several hours for cleanup before reopening around 1 p.m. The cause of the fire is still unknown, and Scottsdale Fire is providing updates.

title: 1 dead after mobile home fire ignites in Mesa
summary: A mobile home fire in Mesa, Arizona, resulted in one fatality, as firefighters discovered a body inside the residence after responding to the blaze on Wednesday afternoon. The fire, which broke out around 3:30 p.m. near Main Street and Alma School Road, temporarily disrupted Valley Metro's light rail service, but normal operations resumed within an hour. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation, and further details about the deceased have not been released.

title: Tempe fire captain returns to work following leg amputation
summary: Tempe Fire Captain Matt Rush is making a remarkable return to work after undergoing a leg amputation due to a severe injury sustained while fighting a fire last year. Initially intended as a knee replacement, the surgery led to complications, resulting in the amputation. Despite the challenges, including 14 surgeries and mental struggles, Rush has embraced his new role by training young firefighters, aiming to inspire them with his resilience. He emphasizes that, although his life has changed, it can still be fulfilling.

title: Scottsdale firefighters rescue boa constrictor trapped inside pickup truck
summary: Scottsdale firefighters recently rescued a large boa constrictor that was trapped inside the engine of a pickup truck. The driver, who was traveling from Mesa to Scottsdale, noticed the snake's head sticking out and called for help. Firefighters carefully removed the truck's undercarriage skid plate to extract the boa, which was unharmed. The snake was then handed over to the Arizona Herpetological Society, and authorities suspect it may have been a missing pet from the Mesa area.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article focuses on the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, emphasizing their prevalence and impact. It discusses various aspects of the wildfires, including weather conditions and their significance in both local and national contexts. The mention of Pinal County suggests that the region is particularly affected or involved in the wildfire events.

title: Surprise firefighter passes away after cancer battle
summary: The Surprise Fire and Medical Department in Arizona is mourning the death of paramedic Paul Johnson, who passed away after a battle with cancer. Johnson, who was recognized as Paramedic of the Year, is remembered for his compassion and dedication to the community. He leaves behind a wife and three young children. The department has expressed their sorrow and commitment to honoring his legacy, and a GoFundMe has been set up to assist with funeral costs.

title: Valley brothers work first shift together at Glendale Fire Department
summary: The Glendale Fire Department recently shared a heartwarming photo on Facebook of brothers Josh and Shane Wright working their first shift together on Engine 154, made possible by a shift trade. The post highlighted the camaraderie among firefighters and celebrated the special bond of family within the department. The brothers enjoyed their time together, embodying the spirit of community and support that characterizes their work.

title: Buckeye firefighter suffers electric shock while battling blaze from porta-potty
summary: A Buckeye firefighter is hospitalized after suffering an electric shock while responding to a house fire that originated in a porta-potty on Wednesday. The incident occurred around 5 p.m. near Irwin Avenue and 5th Street. While the firefighter is in stable condition at the Valleywise Burn Center, the extent of their injuries remains unknown. The fire displaced a family of three, and the Red Cross is assisting them with shelter. The cause of the fire is currently under investigation.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article focuses on the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting their prevalence and impact in the region. It emphasizes the weather conditions contributing to the situation and includes references to local news in Pinal County related to the wildfires.

title: Human-caused fire burns 40 acres in Tonto National Forest
summary: A wildfire, known as the #SkittleFire, is currently burning approximately 40 acres in the Tonto National Forest near Sugarloaf Mountain, Arizona. As of Sunday evening, the fire is 50% contained. It has been determined to be human-caused, and fire crews, including three engines and law enforcement, are actively working to control the blaze.

title: Flood Fire burns roughly 4,400 acres in Pinal County; 80% contained
summary: The Flood Fire in Pinal County, Arizona, has burned approximately 4,400 acres and is currently 80% contained. The fire, which started near Oracle Junction, prompted temporary evacuations in the Panther Butte neighborhood and Palo Verde Ranch due to high winds that exacerbated its spread. However, evacuations were lifted the same day, and there are no ongoing road closures. Crews continue to monitor the fire's perimeter for any remaining heat or smoke.

title: IRS providing relief to Watch Fire victims in San Carlos Apache Tribe
summary: The IRS has announced tax relief for wildfire victims on the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation in Arizona, extending deadlines for those affected by last summer's Watch Fire until February 3. This applies to payments and deadlines that began on July 10, but does not extend to any payments due before the wildfire. The Watch Fire, which started on July 11, resulted in over 400 evacuations, the destruction of 13 homes, and left 75 people homeless. A 22-year-old man was later arrested for allegedly starting the fire.

title: New sawmill opens outside of Flagstaff to help prevent wildfires
summary: A new sawmill, the largest in the Southwest, has opened near Flagstaff, Arizona, aimed at aiding Coconino County's forest restoration efforts to prevent wildfires. With wildfires having burned over a quarter million acres in the area since 2010, the sawmill will process 120 million board feet of lumber annually, supporting restoration on about 30,000 acres and creating 170 jobs. The county's initiatives, which include significant investments in forest management and post-wildfire flood prevention, are receiving attention from federal officials, highlighting the importance of sustainable forest practices.

title: Pinal County community must prepare to evacuate Whitlow Fire burns 218 acres
summary: A wildfire known as the Whitlow Fire has prompted evacuation preparations in the small community of Queen Valley, Arizona, as it has burned 218 acres and is currently 40% contained. The fire, which started on Saturday near Hewitt Station Road, is being fought by multiple firefighting teams, including air support. Residents are on "READY" status and must be prepared to evacuate if conditions worsen. Firefighters face extreme heat, with temperatures exceeding 100 degrees, posing additional challenges in their efforts to control the blaze.

title: Fall Fire burns over 400 acres in Gila River Indian Community; evacuations lifted
summary: A wildfire, known as the Fall Fire, has burned over 400 acres in the Gila River Indian Community, located southwest of Loop 202 and 17th Avenue. The fire, which started as a two-acre blaze, is currently 0% contained, prompting evacuations of nearby homes. However, power has been restored and residents have been allowed to return home, with no reported injuries or damage to structures so far. Firefighting efforts included the use of air tankers to drop fire retardant.

title: Diamond Fire cause ‘inconclusive;’ investigator says scene not secured
summary: The cause of the Diamond Fire, which burned 2,000 acres northeast of Scottsdale in June 2023, has been ruled inconclusive, previously suspected to be arson. Aaron Casem, the state prevention chief, noted that the investigation was hindered due to the scene not being secured, with construction crews present shortly after the fire started, potentially compromising key evidence. Scottsdale Fire Chief Tom Shannon acknowledged the challenges in preserving evidence during the urgent response to fast-moving fires, emphasizing that the priority is to protect life and property.

title: SR 87 reopens between Phoenix area, Payson following brush fire
summary: State Route 87, also known as the Beeline Highway, has reopened following a brush fire that led to its closure between the Phoenix area and Payson. The fire, which was sparked by a semi-truck incident about 12 miles north of the Bush Highway, burned 6 acres and was quickly contained. While northbound lanes reopened around 9:15 p.m. on Thursday and southbound lanes at 5:30 a.m. on Friday, crews are still working to remove the burned-out semi-truck from the roadway.

title: Yarnell communities told to prepare for possible evacuations due to Crest Way Fire
summary: A wildfire known as the Crest Way Fire prompted temporary evacuations in Yarnell, AZ, affecting residents east of State Route 89, particularly around Yarnell Creek. Approximately 14 homes were evacuated, but residents were allowed to return by 5 p.m. Firefighters were on the scene managing the situation, and while the area was under a pre-evacuation status, those warnings have since been lifted for nearby communities.

title: Public asked to avoid area as Siphon Fire grows to roughly 16,000 acres in Superstition Wilderness
summary: The Siphon Fire in the Superstition Wilderness, near Apache Junction, Arizona, has grown to approximately 16,000 acres and is 58% contained as of September 18. While evacuation orders for the Canyon Lake/Tortilla Flat area have been lifted, officials advise the public to avoid certain trails and roads. Firefighters are focusing on improving fire lines and monitoring hot spots, although fire behavior remains erratic. Residents in nearby areas have been placed on READY or SET status for potential evacuations. Lost Dutchman State Park is closed until further notice.

title: Point Fire burns 5,000+ acres northeast of New River
summary: A wildfire known as the Point Fire has burned over 5,664 acres northeast of New River, Arizona, and is currently 42% contained. Firefighters are actively working to protect properties and have managed to contain the blaze between specific forest roads, although flames have spread into the Spur Cross area. Residents in nearby Cave Creek may see some smoke, but no neighborhoods are currently threatened. An investigation into the cause of the fire is ongoing.

title: Gate Fire stopped at 75 acres near north Scottsdale homes
summary: Firefighters successfully contained the Gate Fire, which threatened homes in north Scottsdale, Arizona, after it burned 75 acres. The blaze, originally reported as the Sand Hills Fire, ignited shortly before 2 p.m. and prompted evacuations in the area. No injuries were reported, aside from one firefighter suffering from heat exhaustion. By Friday evening, the fire was fully contained, and residents were allowed to return home. Some trails and the nearby McDowell Mountain Regional Park remain closed as the cause of the fire is still under investigation.

title: Hazy day in Arizona as wildfires scorch California, other Western states
summary: Wildfires in Southern California are causing haze and smoke to spread across Arizona, with three major fires expanding rapidly and resulting in injuries and significant property damage. In Wrightwood, residents have been ordered to evacuate as the Bridge Fire threatens homes and other structures. The wildfires, fueled by a recent heat wave, are also affecting areas in Idaho, Oregon, and Nevada, prompting evacuations for tens of thousands. President Biden is monitoring the situation and urging residents to follow evacuation orders as firefighters work to control multiple blazes.

title: Arizona crews aid in battling fast-moving wildfire east of Los Angeles
summary: A fast-moving wildfire, known as the Line Fire, is threatening over 35,000 structures east of Los Angeles, prompting evacuation orders in several areas. The fire, which has burned more than 20,000 acres near the San Bernardino National Forest, is fueled by extreme temperatures, dry vegetation, and thunderstorms that could exacerbate the situation. Over 600 firefighters, including a crew from the Flagstaff Fire Department, are working to control the blaze, which began Thursday evening and is currently under investigation.

title: Lightning-caused Wood Fire grows to over 7,000 acres near Superior
summary: A wildfire known as the Wood Fire, sparked by lightning near Superior, AZ, has expanded to over 7,194 acres since it began on Sunday. The fire is burning in remote areas of Tonto National Forest, making it difficult for firefighters to access. Residents in certain neighborhoods have been placed on "READY-Prepare Now" status in anticipation of possible evacuation orders. Although the fire is classified as low-intensity, firefighting efforts include ground crews and aerial support.

title: Firework thrown from car window allegedly caused destructive California wildfire
summary: A 26-year-old man, Spencer Grant Anderson, has been charged with starting a destructive wildfire in California by throwing a firework from his car window during hot and windy conditions. The Thompson fire, which erupted on July 2, scorched nearly 6 square miles and destroyed 13 homes in the Oroville area. After weeks of investigation, Anderson was arrested on August 22 and faces multiple arson charges. He is currently held without bail and is scheduled to return to court for further proceedings.

title: McDowell Mountain Regional Park closed due to wildfire near Fountain Hills
summary: McDowell Mountain Regional Park in Fountain Hills, AZ, has been closed due to a wildfire known as the McDowell Fire, which has burned 90 acres and is currently 80% contained. Firefighters initially used air support but quickly established a ground presence to control the blaze, which is not threatening any homes or buildings, and no injuries have been reported. The fire's cause remains unknown, and the park will remain closed while crews continue monitoring and securing the area.

title: Railroad maintenance cause of summer’s destructive Rose Fire near Wickenburg
summary: The Rose Fire, which devastated 166 acres near Wickenburg, Arizona, was determined to have been caused by railroad maintenance operations. Investigators found that sparks from cutting railroad tracks initiated the wildfire, which occurred from June 12 to 17 and resulted in the destruction of 15 structures, vehicles, and utility infrastructure, alongside a closure of U.S. 60. The estimated damage cost is around $971,000, with significant personal losses reported, including the childhood home of resident Kara Engemann-Tracy. BNSF, the railroad company involved, stated their commitment to preventing future fires and assisting affected communities.

title: Arizona wildfire activity trending higher than last year
summary: Wildfire activity in Arizona is on the rise compared to last year, with human-caused fires making up 67% of incidents this year. The increase is attributed to factors such as enhanced vegetation from spring rains and dry summer conditions, along with significant lightning strikes from recent monsoonal activity. Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management officials are urging residents to remain vigilant and take preventive measures, especially as the wildfire outlook extends into October.

title: Bartlett Lake Marina reopens following nearby wildfires
summary: Bartlett Lake Marina has reopened after being closed for about four days due to a wildfire that sparked nearby. Owner Bryan Church noted that this year has seen an unusual number of closures, with the marina having to shut down five times due to wildfires. Despite the challenges, Church expressed gratitude for the support from the community and the efforts of fire crews in protecting the marina. While the marina's facilities are now open, there are still closures on the north side of the lake, particularly in the campgrounds, with no set date for their reopening.

title: Farm Fire burning west of Prescott, evacuations lifted
summary: A wildfire known as the Farm Fire, burning approximately 25 miles west of Prescott, Arizona, has prompted evacuations in a neighborhood near Hillside. The fire has affected between 120 to 150 acres, but evacuation orders for residents on Iron Horse Road were lifted around 6 p.m. The Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management is actively working with local fire districts to control the blaze, which was aided by rainfall that helped slow its spread. There are currently no details on the fire's cause.

title: Several fires burn in Tonto National Forest; recreation sites evacuated
summary: Crews are battling multiple wildfires in Tonto National Forest, sparked by thunderstorms that resulted in around 800 lightning strikes. While no buildings or homes have been damaged, recreation sites and campgrounds near Bartlett and Horseshoe lakes have been evacuated. The Sandstone Fire has burned over 27,000 acres and the Skeleton Fire has consumed around 24,034 acres, with the latter 30% contained. Other fires, including the Clair Fire and Bartlett Fire, are also active, prompting closures of nearby recreational areas. Efforts to control the fires are complicated by hot weather and rugged terrain.

title: Some residents placed in SET status due to 2 wildfires burning near Kingman
summary: Severe thunderstorms in Arizona have led to the outbreak of two wildfires, the Left Fork and Element fires, near Kingman. The Element Fire has grown to nearly 4,000 acres, prompting the Mohave County Sheriff’s Office to place residents in the Vock Canyon area and along Stockton Hill Road in "SET" evacuation status, indicating they should be prepared to leave if necessary. Firefighters are actively working to contain the fires and protect local structures. Residents are encouraged to stay informed through emergency alerts and preparedness resources.

title: Tracking wildfires across Arizona
summary: Arizona is anticipating a high risk of wildfires during the summer of 2024 due to extreme heat and a drier-than-normal monsoon season. Arizona’s Family is actively tracking the wildfires across the state and provides a database for current wildfire information.

title: Wally Fire leads to SET status for some Tonto Basin residents
summary: Residents in Tonto Basin, Arizona, have been placed on SET status due to the Wally Fire, which was ignited by lightning and has burned approximately 450 acres southwest of the area. The Gila County Division of Emergency Management has advised those on the west side of state Route 188 to prepare for potential evacuation. Approximately 75 personnel, along with aerial support, are working to combat the fire. Additionally, there are reports of the Asher Fire burning nearby, leading to evacuations in some campgrounds and recreational sites.

title: 7,000 lightning strikes in northern Arizona keep fire crews busy
summary: In northern Arizona, particularly in Coconino County, recent monsoon storms have resulted in approximately 7,000 lightning strikes, prompting significant activity from fire crews. Over the weekend, 21 initial attack teams were dispatched to manage multiple lightning-caused fires in the area. With an average of 30,000 lightning strikes annually, fire officials emphasize the importance of a swift response for fire suppression, especially given the severity of the wildfire season nationwide. Residents are advised to call 911 for fires on their property and report any forest fires to the Forest Service.

title: SR 87 reopens, ‘SET’ status lifted as Sand Stone Fire continues to burn near Fountain Hills
summary: The Sand Stone Fire near Fountain Hills, Arizona, has burned 27,390 acres and is 82% contained as of Monday evening. State Route 87 has reopened after being closed since Sunday due to the fire, which was ignited by lightning and continues to grow. The Maricopa County Sheriff's Office lifted evacuation preparations for residents in Sunflower to a "READY" status, urging them to have an emergency plan. Firefighters are facing challenges from dry conditions and expected wind gusts, complicating efforts to contain the fire.

title: Lightning-caused wildfire closes north Scottsdale preserve
summary: A lightning-caused wildfire, named the Ricky Fire, is currently burning approximately 10 acres in the McDowell Sonoran Preserve near north Scottsdale. Crews from the Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management have begun containment efforts and are mopping up hotspots. As a precaution, all Preserve lands north of Dynamite Road have been closed, although the fire does not pose an immediate threat to the public. Residents are advised to stay alert for any emergency updates due to potentially changing wind conditions.

title: Arson suspect accused of starting Watch Fire near San Carlos arrested
summary: Keanu Dude, a 22-year-old, has been arrested for allegedly starting the Watch Fire on the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation, which burned over 2,162 acres and destroyed 21 homes earlier this month. The fire forced the evacuation of over 400 tribe members and resulted in a state of emergency. San Carlos Apache Tribe Chairman Terry Rambler expressed sorrow over the incident and emphasized the community's need to recover from the devastation caused by this senseless act of arson. Governor Katie Hobbs has also authorized funds to assist those affected.

title: Some residents on ‘Set’ status as Romero Fire burns 6,900 acres in Pinal County
summary: A wildfire known as the Romero Fire has burned approximately 7,000 acres in Pinal County, Arizona, and is currently 30% contained. Residents of 3C Ranch have been put on 'SET' status, meaning they should prepare for possible evacuation. The fire is located near Kearny and Mammoth and is spreading due to gusty winds, although firefighters have managed to protect nearby structures. Another fire, the Circle Fire, is also burning in the area, affecting over 2,800 acres and is 10% contained. The cause of the Romero Fire remains unknown. Residents are advised to stay clear of the area to aid firefighting efforts.

title: Lightning sparks 3 new wildfires in Tonto National Forest near Cave Creek
summary: Three new wildfires, sparked by lightning, have ignited in Tonto National Forest near Cave Creek, Arizona. The Deer Fire has burned approximately 100 acres, while the Davenport Fire, which started later, has consumed 75-100 acres. The Cane Fire, igniting on the same day, has burned around 50 acres. All fires are not threatening any nearby communities, but officials are advising the public to avoid certain areas and trails due to smoke and fire activity.

title: Evacuations ordered as Black Fire burns thousands of acres in Tonto National Forest
summary: Evacuation orders are in effect as the Black Fire continues to burn in Tonto National Forest, having consumed over 11,100 acres since its ignition on July 11. The fire, caused by lightning, is currently 85% contained, and several communities in Tonto Basin have been ordered to evacuate. A call center has been established to assist residents, and a virtual public meeting will be held for updates. Certain areas of the forest are closed, and resources deployed to combat the fire include personnel, helicopters, and various firefighting equipment.

title: Arizona attorney general calls on FEMA to recognize extreme heat, wildfire smoke as disasters
summary: Arizona Attorney General Kris Mayes, along with 13 other state attorneys general, is urging FEMA to recognize extreme heat and wildfire smoke as major disasters due to their increasing severity linked to climate change. In a letter sent to FEMA, they highlighted the rising heat-related deaths in Maricopa County, which have surged significantly compared to last year. Experts emphasize that these environmental challenges, intensified by greenhouse gas emissions, are causing serious health risks and more frequent wildfires, prompting the need for updated federal regulations to better prepare states for these disasters.

title: Watch Fire 100% contained after burning over 2,000 acres in eastern Arizona
summary: The Watch Fire has been fully contained after burning 2,162 acres on the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation, resulting in the evacuation of over 400 people and the destruction of at least 13 homes, leaving 75 individuals homeless. Authorities are investigating arson as the potential cause of the fire. Residents are urged to stay away from burned areas due to hazardous materials, and Stage 1 Fire Restrictions remain in effect. The fire has had a significant emotional impact on the community, with many residents expressing heartbreak over their losses.

title: Apex Fire burns 3,100 acres southwest of Grand Canyon; 40% contained
summary: The Apex Fire in northern Arizona has burned approximately 3,100 acres, located about 23 miles southwest of the Grand Canyon, and is currently 40% contained. Around 50 firefighters are working to control the blaze, which is being fueled by pinyon pine, juniper, and sagebrush, while outflow winds are increasing fire activity. Crews are focusing on securing the fire's northeast and north sides to protect the nearby Kaibab National Forest, although the flames are not threatening any structures at this time. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

title: San Carlos Apache Tribe resident sees destroyed home after wildfire ripped through community
summary: Sheila Patten, a resident of the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation, returned to find her home destroyed by the Watch Fire, which is suspected to be arson. The fire engulfed over 2,000 acres and destroyed more than a dozen homes, forcing hundreds to evacuate. Sheila lost her home of nearly 60 years, along with personal belongings and vehicles, and is now staying with her family at an evacuation center. Despite the devastation, she remains hopeful about rebuilding in the future, as a fundraiser has been set up to assist her and her family.

title: United Food Bank launches emergency initiative to help San Carlos in aftermath of Watch Fire
summary: The United Food Bank has launched an emergency initiative to assist the San Carlos Apache Tribe in Arizona following the Watch Fire, which has left 75 people homeless after destroying 13 homes. The Mesa-based nonprofit will provide food and clean drinking water, including emergency food boxes for those unable to reach distribution sites. The fire has burned over 2,162 acres and is 81% contained, with arson suspected as the cause. Arizona Governor Katie Hobbs has allocated $400,000 in support, and federal funds have been authorized to aid in fire response. Donations are being organized through partnerships with local ministries.

title: The dangers of Arizona’s abandoned mineshafts while fighting wildfires
summary: Arizona's abandoned mineshafts, remnants of its mining history, pose significant dangers to firefighters battling wildfires. Acting fire operations chief Billy Morris highlighted the risks of falling into these shafts, which can exceed 100 feet in depth and are often difficult to spot during intense fire conditions. Firefighters aim to map these mineshafts ahead of time to avoid accidents, as they can also contain hazardous materials and structural issues. Fortunately, medical teams at wildfire sites are typically equipped to assist in case of falls.

title: Freeman Fire burns 32,568 acres north of Tucson; 85% contained
summary: The Freeman Fire, which started in the Black Mountains of southern Arizona due to two lightning strikes, has burned approximately 32,568 acres and is now 85% contained. Firefighting crews have successfully contained the blaze along several flanks, although it continues to pose a threat to nearby infrastructure, including power lines and a communications tower. Residents of Willow Springs Ranch were previously under evacuation orders, but those have since been lifted. The fire was initially named the Wash Fire before being renamed to Freeman.

title: Pius Fire burns almost 2,000 acres northeast of Payson; 77% contained
summary: The Pius Fire, which began Monday afternoon in the Apache-Sitgreaves National Forests, has burned nearly 2,000 acres northeast of Payson, Arizona, and is currently 77% contained. Smoke from the fire is visible from space and is affecting nearby regions, prompting evacuation orders around Bear Canyon Lake and a pre-evacuation status for Knoll Lake. Firefighting efforts involve 346 personnel and various equipment, but hot and dry conditions are challenging the response. The cause of the fire remains unknown.

title: Watch Fire grows to over 2,100 acres in eastern Arizona; arson suspected
summary: The Watch Fire in eastern Arizona has grown to over 2,162 acres, leading the San Carlos Apache Tribe to declare a state of emergency and evacuate over 400 residents. The fire, suspected to be caused by arson, has destroyed at least 13 homes and left 75 people homeless. FEMA has authorized federal funds to aid in firefighting efforts, and Arizona Governor Katie Hobbs is providing $400,000 in disaster assistance. The tribe emphasizes the need to catch those responsible for the fire and has expressed deep concern for the affected families.

title: Arizona Humane Society sends team to help pets injured in the Watch Fire
summary: The Arizona Humane Society has dispatched a disaster team to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation to assist with pets affected by the Watch Fire, which has left many residents homeless and injured animals in need of care. Currently, 15 dogs, six puppies, and three cats are being treated at an evacuation center set up at the Apache Gold Casino & Resort. The fire has consumed approximately 2,162 acres and is suspected to be caused by arson, with containment efforts still at 0%.

title: Hillside Fire burns about 800 acres near Congress; 88% contained
summary: The Hillside Fire near Congress, Arizona, has burned approximately 818 acres and is now 88% contained. The fire, believed to have been started by lightning, is no longer threatening the community, and the Yavapai County Sheriff’s Office has lifted the SET status for several zones. Roadblocks in the area are set to be lifted by 6 p.m. on Friday, while firefighters continue to patrol the fire's perimeter for any remaining heat sources.

title: Forward progress stopped as Butte Fire burns near Apache Lake in Tonto National Forest
summary: Firefighters are currently battling the Butte Fire in Tonto National Forest, Arizona, which started on Thursday evening near Apache Lake. The wildfire has burned approximately 117 acres and is 40% contained, with forward progress halted as of Friday afternoon. The fire was ignited by a lightning strike, and while nearby areas, including a marina and private residences, are not currently threatened, access roads were temporarily closed to facilitate firefighting efforts. Multiple resources, including engines and specialized crews, are on site to manage the blaze.

title: Gemstone Fire burns 177 acres east of Kingman; 75% contained
summary: The Gemstone Fire, which has burned approximately 177 acres east of Kingman, Arizona, is now 75% contained as of Friday night. The fire, which threatened over 150 buildings and infrastructure, received some rain and is being monitored by about 60 firefighters on the scene. Fortunately, no homes have been evacuated, and the cause of the fire remains unclear. Fire crews will continue to patrol the area to ensure no remaining heat hazards.

title: Wildfire risk rises as Western states dry out amid protracted heat wave
summary: Authorities in Western states are warning of an increased risk of wildfires due to a prolonged heat wave that has dried out the landscape and set record temperatures. California has already responded to over 3,500 wildfires this year, burning nearly five times the average area compared to previous years. Firefighters are battling several blazes, including a significant one in Santa Barbara County, while Oregon and Washington have implemented burn bans to prevent further fires. Forecasts suggest some relief may come by the weekend, but the fire danger remains high.

title: Duck Lake fire burns 31 acres in eastern Arizona
summary: A slow-moving wildfire, known as the Duck Lake fire, has burned about 31 acres in eastern Arizona since it was discovered on July 5. The fire, sparked by lightning, is occurring in an area with many dead trees, which could fuel its spread. Two fire engines are on-site to manage the blaze, and while no roads or trails are closed and no buildings are threatened, visitors are advised against camping nearby due to potential smoke visibility.

title: Alleged firefighter impersonator accused of telling residents to evacuate due to Hillside Fire, causing panic
summary: A man named Patrick Parent has been arrested in Yavapai County, Arizona, for allegedly impersonating a firefighter and falsely telling residents to evacuate due to the ongoing Hillside Fire. His actions caused panic among the community, despite no official evacuation orders being issued. The Yavapai County Sheriff’s Office confirmed that Parent, who had previously been with the fire department, was not authorized to make such announcements. He faces multiple charges, including DUI and impersonating a public servant, after being found with fire department clothing and evidence of impairment.

title: Residents return to ‘READY’ status as Shake Fire breaks out in Pinal County
summary: Evacuations in the Kearny area of Pinal County, AZ, have been lifted as firefighters successfully contained the Shake Fire and Ray Fire, both of which were reported to be 100% contained on Thursday. Residents previously under evacuation orders have been returned to a 'READY' status, allowing them to return home. The Shake Fire, which burned approximately 110 acres and was determined to be human-caused, faced challenges due to hot temperatures, winds, and dry vegetation. FEMA has approved assistance for firefighting costs related to the incidents.

title: Pinal County residents return home as Ray Fire burns near Kearny
summary: Residents of Pinal County can now return home as firefighters have made significant progress against the Ray Fire near Kearny, which is now 100% contained. The fire, which was human-caused, burned approximately 51 acres. Evacuation statuses for affected residents have been downgraded to "READY," and a nearby highway that had been closed due to the fire has reopened. Firefighting efforts included the use of air tankers and hand crews from the Arizona Department of Forestry and Fire Management.

summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting their prevalence and impact on the region. It emphasizes the severity of the situation, with multiple mentions of wildfires affecting various areas in Arizona, particularly in Pinal County. title: Why firefighters were delayed to house fires in Yavapai County community
summary: A recent fire in Paulden, Arizona, destroyed four homes, raising concerns about the lack of fire coverage in the community. Paulden relies on a subscription fire service, Central Arizona Fire and Medical Authority (CAFMA), but many homeowners do not pay for the service, resulting in delayed responses during emergencies. The incident highlighted ongoing issues in the area, where residents often assume they have fire protections similar to urban areas, despite the absence of a local fire department and the necessity for a subscription fee.

title: Wind-driven fire destroy four homes in northern Arizona community
summary: A wind-driven fire in Paulden, Arizona, destroyed four homes on Thursday, leaving four families displaced. The fire originated in one home and quickly spread to neighboring properties, prompting neighbors to attempt to extinguish the flames before firefighters arrived. Fortunately, there were no injuries reported, but some victims lost their pets and belongings. The local community is rallying to support those affected, with a nearby food bank collecting donations. An investigation into the cause of the fire is ongoing.

title: Arizona firefighter battling rare cancer, neurological issues
summary: Matt McFadden, a 35-year-old firefighter from Prescott Valley, Arizona, is battling testicular cancer and neurological issues that may be job-related. After experiencing slurred speech and balance problems, he was diagnosed with cancer following a departmental screening. The cancer has metastasized to his lungs, and he is undergoing chemotherapy while doctors investigate the neurological symptoms, which could indicate a rare condition linked to the cancer. His wife, Kahley, has taken on additional responsibilities at home, including caring for their special needs daughter.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, emphasizing the frequency and severity of these events. It highlights the impact of weather conditions on the wildfires and mentions related news from Pinal County. The repetitive use of "wildfires" indicates a significant concern regarding their prevalence in the region.

title: Yuma firefighters remember 9/11 with symbolic stair climb
summary: The Yuma Firefighter Association commemorated the 9/11 attacks by organizing a stair climb event, where firefighters and community members climbed 110 floors to honor the nearly 3,000 victims, including 343 firefighters. David Padilla from the Yuma Fire Department emphasized the emotional significance of the day, stating it serves as a reminder to keep the memories of those lost alive and to educate younger generations about the sacrifices made. Over 30 participants completed the climb, reinforcing the commitment to "never forget."

title: Yuma residents upset about house fire they say could have been prevented
summary: Residents in Yuma, AZ, are expressing frustration over a recent house fire that destroyed a vacant property and numerous inoperable vehicles, claiming it could have been prevented if code enforcement had acted on their complaints. One resident, Ruth Leal, reported multiple attempts to contact code compliance about the unsafe conditions, including overgrown trees and accumulated vehicles, but received no response. The Yuma Fire Department responded to the fire, which was initially reported as a palm tree on fire, but upon arrival discovered the entire property engulfed in flames. Following the incident, the code compliance department has initiated an investigation to address the property issues.

title: Yuma’s historic train depot demolished months after suspected arson
summary: The Southern Pacific Freight Depot, one of Yuma's oldest buildings, has been demolished following a suspected arson fire in March. The depot, which was the first train depot in Arizona, was considered a significant loss to the city's historic downtown. While plans for its restoration were previously in place, Yuma officials are now reworking development plans for the site, including the establishment of an Innovation Hub to promote entrepreneurship. Mayor Douglas Nicholls emphasized the importance of preserving the area's history while looking toward future developments.

title: Arizona Wildfires
summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, highlighting their prevalence and impact in the region. It emphasizes the severity of the situation and the associated weather conditions affecting the area. The mention of Pinal County indicates that the wildfires may also be relevant to local news in that region.

title: Father in coma with third-degree burns after getting shocked by power line at work
summary: Michael "Mike" Papagno, a 33-year-old electrician, is in a medically induced coma at a Boston hospital after suffering third-degree burns to half his body from a power line shock while at work in New Hampshire on November 12. His family is facing a challenging recovery process, with Mike having undergone several surgeries and potentially needing more. They remain hopeful due to his age and strength, and a GoFundMe campaign has raised over $176,000 to assist with medical expenses and lost income. His family describes him as a lively and dedicated father, eagerly anticipating his recovery.

summary: The article discusses the ongoing wildfires in Northern Arizona, emphasizing their prevalence and impact on the region.
